EN

Bitcoin tumbled to around $65,000 following over $1.5 billion in liquidations, but the Relative Strength Index (RSI) has dropped to 17.6. This marks the third most oversold condition in Bitcoin's history, surpassed only by the 2018 market bottom and the 2020 Covid crash. Historically, such extreme readings have preceded major recoveries, with previous instances leading to price quadrupling or reaching new cycle highs. Despite current bearish sentiment, analysts view the deep oversold territory as a buying opportunity. The recent market action has effectively wiped out liquidity between $70,000 and $80,000, suggesting that if a reversal occurs, it could result in a rapid and violent upward move for Bitcoin.

Key Points

  • Bitcoin's daily RSI fell to 17.6, the third lowest reading ever, indicating extreme oversold conditions.
  • Historical parallels from 2018 and 2020 suggest similar lows have preceded massive price rallies.
  • The market saw over $1.5 billion in liquidations as Bitcoin dropped to $65,000.
  • Traders are eyeing the lack of liquidity between $70,000 and $80,000 as a catalyst for a potential surge.

Article

Bitcoin is the third most oversold ever, says one indicator, and violent upside could be next The Relative Strength Index (RSI), a popular technical trading indicator, has plunged to 17. Only the bear market bottom in 2018 and the 2020 Covid crash saw lower reads. Updated Feb 5, 2026, 7:51 p.m. Published Feb 5, 2026, 7:34 p.m. Bitcoin tumbled to around $65,000 on Thursday amid a wave of liquidations driven by heavily bearish sentiment, but one technical indicator suggests the cryptocurrency could be set for not just a bounce, but a major move higher. Bitcoin's daily Relative Strength Index (RSI), which is a popularly used momentum oscillator that assesses whether an asset is oversold or overbought, flashed 17.6 (on a scale of 0-100) on Thursday ‚Äî heavily oversold conditions that were topped in the modern BTC era by the Covid crash in 2020, when it fell to 15.6, and the 2018 market bottom, when it dropped to 9.5. STORY CONTINUES BELOW On both of those previous occasions, bitcoin rewarded buyers with violent upside moves. In 2018, BTC more than quadrupled over the ensuing 8 months from $3,150 to $13,800. In 2020, bitcoin soared from $3,900 to a cycle high of $65,000 just more than one year later. Thursday's market carnage liquidated more than $1.5 billion across crypto derivatives. While the temptation might be to sell when an asset is weak, astute traders will see the oversold territories as an opportunity ‚Äî especially as liquidity between $70,000 and $80,000 has effectively been wiped out.
